q: Zahi Hawass , nothing was stolen from the Egyptian Museum and the 70 damaged pieces can all be repaired. But Dreyfus wonders about the mummies. "You can't repair a mummy," she says. If you have a body that's no longer intact, how are you going to perform any kind of examination of it? It's now contaminated. Dreyfus still can't quite fathom how people, no matter how dire their economic situation, could smash artifacts of their ancient civilization. "Why would you want to destroy history at a time

antiquities Zahi Hawass said that during the revolt several major artefacts had been stolen from the Egyptian museum, including a statue of Tutankhamun, better known as King Tut. The objects missing from the famed museum include a gilded wood statue of the 18th Dynasty king Tutankhamun being carried by a goddess and parts of another statue showing him harpooning, he said. Looters had broken into the museum off Cairo's Tahrir Square on January 28, during clashes between protesters and riot police. Meanwhile

Tom Watson, the former defence minister who used his seat on the culture select committee to chase down Andy Coulson , said his departure creates serious questions over the prime minister's judgment and points to the need for a deeper investigation into the affairs of Rupert Murdoch 's News Corp. Rupert Murdoch is waiting to hear if his bid will be referred to the Competition Commission.
